Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 06:13AM AmyElvira wrote: When I was going through chemo I did not wear a wig because I found it uncomfortable.  I wore a knit hat most of the time - but it was pretty obvious I was bald.  I work in an office and a sales guy came in one day.  I didn't really know him, but evidently he had heard from someone that I had breast cancer.  He started telling me about his sister-in-law who was my age and died of BC the previous year.  Thanks guy - that makes me feel so much better!!  Like Leah said - you can't cure stupidity!!

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 06:16AM AmyElvira wrote: My bilateral mastectomy was two years ago.  The first time we had sex after my surgery, I cried and cried.  I can tell you that time does heal a lot, physically and emotionally... but it doesn't heal everything.  I still prefer to wear a tank top when having sex - and my husband never touches my chest.  I miss my breasts, and I know he does too.  What a crappy deal!!!  Barbe - urge your DH to have his testoterone level checked. When guys get older, testosterone goes down, and this can lead to reduced labido.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 02:10PM AmyElvira wrote: CoolBreeze ~ One thing I learned through my ordeal two years ago is this: Stand up for yourself no matter what.  If waiting that long is unacceptable to you - tell them that and find out what they are going to do about it.  Don't stop pushing until you get your way.  This is your body - your life - your treatment - your decision.  Don't let anyone tell you "how it's going to be". I felt a lump in my breast for two years. Doctors, radiologists, sonographers and surgeons told me it was nothing but a grouping of "harmless cysts".  I finally put my foot down and INSISTED they take it out.  They rolled their eyes at me, but they did it.  And guess what - it was cancer.  I saved my own life by standing up for myself. You go girl!! Amy
